+Ronin Dave The misinfirmation that Anna's peddling is that this is down to 
the fact that its because she us a woman. 

A subordinate can earn a higher salary than the person they report to. 
There are numerous scenarios where this could happen. A perfect example in 
a corporate environment is when management shuffles roles around to make 
their escalation procedures more efficient.

Second comes down to negotiating power. When a company hires a new employee 
they always offer them the least amount of money they're willing to pay, 
but they always set up a max range that they'd accept should the new 
employee demand a higher salary than originally listed. If an employee has 
the temerity to demand the a higher salary, gueas what, they could probably 
earn more thsn their boss who chose to accept the minimum original salary 
the company offer.

3rd is simply time at work. If an employee's been working for a company 
longer, has asked for & recieved raises it's possible that a new boss might 
actually be offered a lower salary anyway.

4th, in some countries in certain roles a company has a legal obligation to 
pay a new employee MORE than they were recieving in their last job. So if 
ine company desperately needs a role filled and the options available to 
them are from people who were earning higher salaries than they pay their 
more senior staff now, they have no option but to pay their new/subordinate 
a higher salary. They are under no obligation to then offer the more senior 
employee more money.

Just to be clear. I know little to nothing about this story.

Now, about this silly argument that goes
Equal work means equal pay.

Here's the real equation

Equal work + equal experience + equal responsibility + equal expectations + 
equal trust = equal pay

Equal experience: Have you done what the previous person in that position 
has done for the same amount of time. If you haven't, odds are you haven't 
dealt with the same contingencies as the previous person.

Equal responsibility: Because you are new, odds are there'll be big calls 
you wont be allowed to make without consulting, and that previous guy was 
probably allowed. That meant you are automatically off the hook for 
screwing up the company big time, at least for a while.

Equal expectations: When you are put in that position, are you expected to 
perform at the same level as everybody else who was there or higher? When I 
was an entry level engineer, I was given small tasks while other engineers 
(same position) were given more important stuff. I was also allowed to take 
a little longer for my tasks. It eventually went away as tasks got bigger 
and deadlines remained the same.

Equal trust (kind of a combination of the previous ones): Does your work go 
unchecked like the work of the previous guy goes? You are new at a position 
and your employer just assumes right off the bat you understand everything 
there is to do and that you are also doing it well?﻿

Here is the example of how equal pay is bullshit:

A boy and a girl with no work experience graduates high school with

day to perform the same work. 5 years go by and they both got raises on the 
same day, so their pay is equal. Both gets married to two different people

as usual expecting a child to be born, but the female has to take maternity 
leave, meaning the company has to make up for the lack of her work. She 
returns of maternity leave after missing a few months worth of work. 2 
years down the line, both decides to have another child, and another and 
another. By the 15th year, the male is making $5K more than the female, but 
the female is claiming discrimination, due to "unequal pay for equal work."

What's the problem with that example? The woman didn't take into account

business of making MONEY. Since she decided to have children, the company 
has to spend money to pay others overtime to make up for her slack or in 
some cases, temporarily hire someone. For the whole 15 years, the male has 
continuously been a productive asset to the company and the company may 
have wanted to retain him. And that's just one factor. 

Bluntly, these are the reasons for "unequal pay for equal work:"

I'm sorry Ana, but the whole wage gap myth exists exactly because certain 
women want to automatically get paid the same as a man, regardless of a 
plethora of other factors influencing wages.

There is no gender wage gap, the difference in aggregate average salaries 
between men and women is almost entirely a function of personal choices; 
what profession, how many hours, how many years on the job, maternity 
leave, overtime, commuting distances, flexible or rigid work hours, working 
from home, health coverage, etc.

Men typically make choices that get them higher salaries, from the 
professions they pursue to the choices they make when they get there, 
whereas women's priorities seem to be more about comfort over profit, like 
flexible working hours, working from home, optional health coverage plans, 
shorter commutes, less overtime work, etc.

The fact that the story about the NYT editor was framed as a "woman victim 
of pay discrimination" just goes to show that the default assumption is 
sexism even when there are tons of alternative explanations and no actual 
data.﻿

The problem though is that often the women make less because they work less 
hours then their male counter parts, and spend less time in their 
respective fields.

If you compare a man working 10~20 extra hours per week, and having worked 
the same position for 3 more years than another male worker in the same 
position working only his hours and having been on the job for 3 less 
years, you will see a disparity in the pay.

This is the huge gap between men and women, when you adjust for that the 
pay gap decreases significantly, and in some areas women are paid more then 
men.

The problem is that women have different goals than men, and different 
social expectations regarding family, and life. It turns out that men tend 
to work themselves hard then women on average because the societal 
expectation is that men's value comes from how they provide for their 
family while a women's value is often how well they raise it.

tl;dr: It's not that women get paid less or same work, it's that women and 
men have different values which leads to disparity in work experience 
between the sexes.
